And bondage will o'ertake them!. They fall off
Like the revolted Tribes . — Ægyptian bondage!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Wherefore so loud good Colonel? Sirs, I shame
To have held ye waiting here., Aa sudden cause,
I pray ye believe it urgentearnest, hindered me.
Where is the wWarrant? Have ye left a space
For my poor name?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou wilt find room enow.
There!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: What unsigned? — Harrison! — He came hither
To crave your signatures.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I did my message!
But these Philistines—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Do ye shame to set
Your names to your own deeds? Did ye not pass

app.rdg: This solemn sentence in the face of day,
This just and solemn sentence in the face of day

sp.l: Before the arraigned King, the shouting people,
The mMajesty of Heaven?

sp.speaker: Tich.
sp.l: Thou dost mistake us.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I crave your pardon, Sirs. I deemed ye were
The jJudges, the King's judges, the Eelect
Of England, chosen by her godly Commons
As wisest, boldest, best. I did mistake ye.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Listen, ere thou accuse us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Listen! Ssign!;
And weI will listen, though your pleaded reason
Outlast Hugh Peter's sSermon.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Hear me first.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Well..

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: We have here Commissioners from Scotland
Praying our mercy on the King.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: They gave him
Into our hands.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: And they are answered Sir.
Thou know'st that Cromwell singly put them down,
As they had been young babes.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: The Pensionary—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Hath sent pressing missives; Embassies
From every court, are on the seas; and& Charles
Proffers great terms.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Have we not all?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: But he
Will give a fair security, a large
And general amnesty. S; so are we freed
From fear of after- reckoning.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Master Cook
No wonder that a lawyer pleads to- day
Against his cause of yesterday —, if fee ' d
To the height. But thou art not of us; thy part
Is o'er.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He will give large securities !—
For what?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: The general safety, &andour own.,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Safety! S, say liberty! Securities.
Many large promises! An ye will trust
Ye may be Earls &and Marquesses, and portion
This pretty iIslet England as a mManor
Amongst ye. Shame ye not to think a bribe
Might win your souls from freedom?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: From the Lord!
Would ye desert Hhis people? sell for gain
His cause?.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Hush! Hush! None thinketh to forsake
The cCause!.

sp.speaker: Tich.
sp.l: Let Bradshaw sign. What need more names
Than the Lord President's?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: I am ready, Sirs,
An ye will follow me. The Instrument
Were else illegal. When ye are prepared,
Speak.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: My good mMasters, ye remember me
Of a passage of my boyhood.
Deem me not
A light unmeaning trifler, r. Recollect
How Nathan spake to David.(then aloud)(aloud) Being a child
Nutting with other imps in the old copse
At Hinchinbroke, we saw across a wide
But shallow stream one overhanging hazel.
Whose lissome stalks were weighed by the rich fruitage
Almost into the water. As we stood
Eyeing the tempting boughs, a shining nut
Fell from its socket, dimpling wide around
The dark clear mirror. At that sight one bold
And hardy urchin, with myself, no less
In those young days a daring wight, at once
Plunged in the sparkling rivulet. It rose
Above our ancles, to our knees, half up
Our thighs, &and my scared comrade in 'the midst
Of the stream turned roaring back, and& gained the bank
Nutless and wet,& wet amidst the scoffing shouts
Of the small people.

sp.speaker: Marten.
sp.l: And thou?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Why I bore
My course right on &, and gained the spoil. Sirs, we
Have plunged knee -deep in the waters;, are mid -way
The stream : W,—w ill ye turn now &and leave the fruit
Ungathered, recreants?, or hold boldly on
And win the holy prize of freedom? Give me
The wWarrant. (signs.)(signs)So! mMethinks an it were not
Over ambitious, and& that's a sin;,
My homely name should stand alone to this
Most righteous scroll. Follow who list.! I've left
A space for the Lord President.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: I'll fill it
With an unworthy name.

sp.speaker: Crom.

app.rdg: Swell the roll fast! Where goest thou Marten? None
My masters! Whither goest thou Marten? None

sp.l: Shall stir till he hath signed. Thou a ripe scholar,
Not write thy name! I can write mine i' the dark,
And oft with my sword-point have traced in air
The viewless characters in the long hour
Before the joy of battle. Shut thine eyes,
And write thy name! Anywhere! See,
Nay, Marten,
Stand still ! —See! See! how fair and& clerkly! Yet
This parchment is the smoother.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hold thee sure
I'll pay thee, General.

sp.speaker: Bradshaw.
sp.l: Why he hath marked thee
Like a new fresh-ruddled sheep.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll pay thee.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sign.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Why so. Where goes
Our zealous alderman? I deemed to see
His name the first.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: He fears the Ccity's safety,
Full, as he says, of the King's friends.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: He fears!
They be bold men who fearlessly do own
Their fears., I dare not. Fear! Sir, didst thou come
By water hither?

sp.speaker: Tich.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: And didst thou meet
No soldiers on thy way?

sp.speaker: Tich.
sp.l: Many. The streets
Are swarming with them.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Were they silent?

sp.speaker: Tich.
sp.l: No.,
They called aloud for execution.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Say,
For justice and& for execution. Marry,
My Ironsidesbold Dragoons know not the new state trick
To separate the words. Well! are not they
A nearer fear? Sign boldly.

rdg.emph: (Cromwell Marten and Downesadvance to the front)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They flock fast.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: 'Tis time,; for plots are weaving round about us,
Like spider's nets in Autumngust. But this morning
I swept one web away. Lord Broghill—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What!
Hath he been here?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Is he discovered?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sir,
I have a slow-hound's scent to track a traitor .—
He's found and, & he's despatched.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: To Ireland,
With a commission 'gainst the rebels. 'Tis
An honest soldier who deserves to fight
The Queen beguiled him, and& the knightly sound
Of lLloyalty. But 'tis an honest soldier.;
He will prove faithful.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How didst win him?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: How?
A word of praise, a thought of fear. How do men
Win traitors? Hark ye, Downes!, Lord Broghill left
A list of the King's friends amongst us here;—
Grave seeming Rroundheads, bold and zealous& pious soldiers,
High officers—I marvel not ye look
Distrustfully—one of renown, a Colonel ,
A Judge too !— Downes , hast thou signed yonder Warrant?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What was the plan?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Go sign I say.—The plan !?
A sudden rescue, to o'erpower the guard.—
Ha! Ingoldsby!

div.stage: (Seizing one of the Judges and going with him to the table.seizing one of the Judges & going with him to the table)

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Nay, man, if thou be questioned,
Some dozen years hence, say that I forced thee, swear

Thy wicked kK insman held thy hand. — Aye ,
nN ow
The blank is nobly filled, &and bravely! now
I know ye once again, the pious Judges

The eE lect and& godly of the land !.—
Good Marten
Haste to my son;, bid him disband his force;
The peril is gone by.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: What peril?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Ye
That are assembled here, should lift your voice
In earnest thanks for for quick deliverance
From sudden danger. Yhidden danger; ye knew nought of this
Great jeopardy, nor need ye know. Give thanks,;
And question not. Ye are safe.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Art sure of that?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Did ye not hear me even now take order
The guard should be dispersed? Question no more.
Ye are so safe, that this slight parchment, Sirs,
May be your shield.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: The deed is incomplete.
It hath no date.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Ah!Ha well reminded! w. Write

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Tomorrow? tThat were sudden.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Why so we must be. There be plots astir
And speed is our best safety.—Thou hast signed ?—
Thy name is here amongst us?Is not thy name among us? —I must haste
To overtake the hour. 'Tis still unsealed.;
Add thou my signet ,Bradshaw.

sp.speaker: Tich.
sp.l: What intends
The General?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Question not of that. A taper!
Your seals, my Lords Commissioners! Your seals!

div.stage:
Enter the King , leading in the Princess Elizabeth
&and the Duke of Gloucester.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here we may weep at leisure. Yon fierce ruffian
Will scarce pursue us here. Elizabeth ,
I thought I had done with anger, but the soldierruffian
Who gazed on thee awhile, with looks that seemed
To wither thy young beauty, &and with words—
My child! my child! And I had not the power
To shield mine own sweet child!

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: I saw him not;
Could hear no voice savebut thine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: When I am gone
Who shall protect thee ?!

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: I shall soon be tall;
And then—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Poor boy! Elizabeth , be thou
A mother to him .! Rear him up in peace
And humbleness. Show him how sweet Content
Can smile on dungeon floors; how the mewed lark
Sings in his narrow cage. Plant pP atience, dear - ones,
Deep in your hearts.
Herbert , where stays the Queen?
Still on that hopeless quest of hope, though friends
Drop from her fast as leaves in Autumn ?.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Sire ,
Craves audience of your Majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Admit him.
Wipe off those tears , Elizabeth. Resume
Thy gentle courage. Thou art a Princess.
Sir ,
Thou seest me with my children. Doth thine errand
Demand their absence?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: No. I sent them to thee
In Cc hristian charity. Thou hast not fallen
Amongst the Heathen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Howsoever sent ,
It was a royal boon. My heart hath ached
With the vain agony of longing love
To look upon those blooming cheeks, to kiss
Those red &and innocent lips, to hear the sound
Of those dear voices.

sp.speaker: Crom.

app.rdg: Sir, 'twas meet to send them they came,

sp.l: That thou might'stmight see them once again, might'stmight say—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Farewell! — I can endure the word—a last
Farewell! I have dwelt so long upon the thought ,
The sound seems nothing. Ye have signed the sentence ? .
Fear not to speak Sir . ?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ye havesigned. And the day?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Tomorrow.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What!
So soon? And yet I thank ye. Speed is mercy.
Ye must away, poor children.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Nay , the c the C hildren
May bide with thee till nightfall.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take them , Herbert!
Take them .!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dear - ones , I go
On a great journey. Bless ye once again,
My children! We must part. Farewell .!

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Oh father ,
Let me go with thee!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Know ' st thou whither?

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Yes;
To Heaven. Oh take me with thee! I must die ;
When the tree falls , the young buds wither. Take me
Along with thee to Heaven! Let us lie
Both in one grave!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now bless ye! This is death ;!
This is the bitterness of love .!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Fair child
Be comforted.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Did ' st thou not pat her head?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: She minded me, all in her innocent tears,
Of one in mine own dwelling.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou hast daughters ;.
Be kind to her.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And the poor boy —,
He comes not near the throne. Make not of him
A puppet King.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I think not of it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take them ,
Good Herbert! And my wife—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: She shall be safe;
She shall home to France unharmed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now fF are ye well!—
Cromwell come back ! —No , bring them not again , —

No more of parting —!b
b B less them! bB less them! See
The girl, the poor poor girl , hath wept away
Her tears , and pants and shivers & pants & shivers like a fawn
Dying. Oh ! for some gentle face to look on
When she revives,awakes or she will surely die .

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: She shall be cared for.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Are they gone? quite gone?
I might have kissed them once again, have charged them

To love each other .
—No ,! 'tis best.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Thou bad'st me
Remain. What is thy will?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be kind to them ,!
Be very kind to them !.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Have I not promised?
Was thatthis what thou would ' st say?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No . But the love,
The o'ermastering love—that was the death-pang . Cromwell,
Thou wiltwilt be kind to them?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Would ' st have me swear?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay, swear not, lestNay swear not lest I doubt. I willwill believe thee.
And for the human pity thou hast shown,
The touch of natural ruth, I pray theeprithee take
My thanks.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I would have saved thee. By this hand,
This sinful hand, I would have saved thee, King,
Had ' st thou flung by yon bauble.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: There is One
From silver-tongued &and bland hH ypocrisy
To treasonous murder. The unspoken thought ,
And the loud lie, &and the accursed act ,
Mount to His throne together. Tempt Him not !.
I know thee for the worker of this deed,
And knowing pardon thee :, —but tempt not Him!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Thy blood be on thy head! I would have saved thee ;—
Even now the thought stirred in me. Pardon, Lord,
That gazing on the father's agonies ,
My heart of flesh waxed faint, &and I forgot

Thy glory &and
Tt hy cause, the suffering saints .
The tyrant's tyranny & T, and thy great word ,
Freedom! Thy blood be on thy head .!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So be it !.

app.rdg:
Charles the First
Act the Fifth.
>(On account of the length of the Tragedy, this scene is omitted in representation.)

div.stage: The King, starting from his couch ;, Herbert asleep.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Herbert! Is't time to rise? He sleeps. What sounds
Were those that roused me? Hark again! The clang
Of hammers! Yet the watch - light burns; the day
Is still unborn. This is a work of night,
Of deep funereal darkness. Each loud stroke
Rings like a knell, distinct, discordant, shrill,
Gathering, redoubling, echoing round my head,
Smiting me only with its sound amid
The slumbering city, tolling in mine ear—
A passing bell! It is the scaffold. Heaven
Grant me to tread it with as calm a heart
As I bear now. His sleep is troubled.Herbert!
'Twere best to wake him. Herbert! rouse thee,Rouse thee man!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Did your Grace call?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye; we should be today
Early astir. I've a great business toward ,;
To exchange the kK ingly wreath, my crown of thorns,
And I would go trim as a bridegroom. Give me
Yon ermined cloak. If the crisp nipping frost
Should cause me shiver, there be tongues would call
The wintery chillness Fear. Herbert , my sleep
Hath been as soft and& balmy , as young babes
Inherit from their blessed innocence ,
Or hardy peasants win with honest toil.
When I awoke thy slumbers were perturbed,
Unquiet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: So please you, Sire, demand not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dost thou think
A dream can vexgrieve me now? Speak.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Thrice I slept,
And thrice I woke, &and thrice the self-same vision
Haunted my fancy. Seemed this very room,
This dim and waning taper, this dark couch,
Beneath whose crimson canopy reclined
A form august &and stately. The pale ray
Of the watch - light dwelt upon his face, and showed& shewed
His paler lineaments, where mM ajesty

And manly beauty,Beauty
&and deep trenching tT hought,
And Care, the wW rinkler, all were blended now
Into one calm and& holy pensiveness ,
Softened by slumber. I stood gazing on him
With weeping love, as one awake; when sudden
A thick &and palpable darkness fell around,
A blindness, &and dull groans and& piercing shrieks
A moment echoed; then they ceased, and& light
Burst forth &and musick,—light such as the flood
Of day-spring at the dawning, rosy , sparkling,

An insupportable brightness !—
aA nd i'th' midst,
Over the couch , a milk-whitemilk white dove, which soared
Right upward, cleaving , with its train of light
The Heavens like a star. The couch remained
Vacant.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh that the spirit so may pass!
So rise! Thrice did ' st thou say?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Three times the vision
Passed o'er my fancy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A thrice-blessedthrice blessed omen!
Herbert , my soul is full of serious joy ,
Content and& peaceful as the Autumn sun ,
When, smiling for awhile on the ripe sheaves
And kissing the brown woods, he bids the world
A calm gG oodnight. Bear witness that I die
In charity with all men ; a. A nd take thou,
My kind and& faithful servant, follower
Of my evil fortunes , true &and tender, take
All that thy master hath to give—his thanks,
His poor but honest thanks .! Another King
Shall better pay thee. Weep not. Seek the Bishop;

And if thou meet with that fair c
Constancy,
My mournful Henrietta, strive to turn
Her steps away till—I'm a coward yet ,
And fear her , lest she come to plunge my thoughts
In the deep fountain of her sad fond tears,
To win me—Ha! cC an that impatient foot,
That hurrying hand , which shakes the door—

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: My Charles!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Haste to the Bishop .!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Charles!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Already here!
Thou did ' st fall trembling in my arms , last night,
Dizzy &and faint &and spent, as the tired martlet,
Midway her voyage , drops panting on the deck ,
And slumbers through the tempest. I kissed off
The tears that hung on thosethy fair eyelids, blessing
Thy speechless weariness, thy weeping love
That sobbed itself to rest. Never did mM other ,
Watching her fevered infant, pray for sleep
So calm, so deep , so long , as I besought
Of Heaven for thee , when half unconscious, yet
Moaning &and plaining like a dove, they bore thee
With gentle force away. And thou art here
Already! wW akened into sense &and life
And the day ' s agony !.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Here! I have been
To Harrison, to Marten, to Lord Fairfax,
To Downes, to Ireton ,— e. E ven at Bradshaw's feet
I've knelt to day. Sleep now? s! S hall I e 'v er sleep
Again!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: At Bradshaw's feet !? Oh perfect love
How can I chide thee? Yet I would thou had ' st spared
Thyself &and me that scorn.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Do Hh unters scorn
The shrill cries of the lioness, whose cubs
They've snared, although the Ff orest-Queen approach
Crouching? Do seamen scorn the forked lightning
They spake of pity; one of hope.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Alas!
All thy life long the torturer hH ope hath been
Thy mM aster!—Yet if she can steal an hour
From grief— wW hom dost thou trust?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thyself &and Heaven
And a relenting woman. Wrap thyself
Close in my cloak—Here! hH ere!— tT o Lady Fairfax!
She's faithful ;, she'll conceal thee .! Take the cloak ;!
Waste not a point of time, not whilst thewhile one grain of sand
Runs in the glass .! Dost fear its shortness? See
How long it is! And I am tall. How oft

app.rdg: In happier days thou hast floated me for height
And stooped in pretty mockery to look
Up at my eyes. On with the cloak! Begone!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And thou?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: My post is here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To perish !

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: No ,;
To live to a blest old age with thee in freedom .!
Away my Charles, my King! I shall be safe—
And if I were not , could I live if thou—
Charles , thou wilt madden me. 'Tis the first boon

I ever craved ;,
&and now , by our young loves,
By our commingled griefs, a mighty spell,
Our smiling children , & and this bleeding land,
Go !, I conjure thee, go!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Begone! or I will speak such truth— and& truth
Is a foul treason in this land—will rain
Such curses on them , as shall force them to send melay

app.rdg: To the scaffold at thy side. Fly!
My head upon the block. Fly! Fly!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Dost thou see
Fierce soldiers crowded round , as if to watch
A garrisoned fort, rather than one unarmed
Defenceless man, &and think ' st thou I could win
A step unchallenged? Nor , though to escape
Were easy as to breathe, the vigilant guard
Smitten with sudden blindness, the unnumbered
And stirring swarms of this vast city locked
In charmed sleep, and& darkness over all
Blacker than starless night, spectral &and dim
As an eclipse at noon - tide, though the gates
Opened before me ,&and my feet were swift
As the Antelope's, not then , if it but perilled
A single hair of friend or foe , would I
Pass o'er the threshold. In my cause too much
Of blood hath fallen. Let mine seal all. I go
To Dd eath as to a bridal; thou thyself
In thy young beauty was not welcomer
Than he. Farewell , beloved wife! My chosen!
My dear - one! We have loved as peasants , sweetest,

app.rdg:
Rather than Princes,
been as fond as they,
As happy & as true. Now Fare thee well!

sp.l: Been fond and& true as they Now fare thee well!
I thank thee ,&and I bless thee. Pray for me,
My Henrietta !.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Charles , thou shalt be saved.
Talk not of parting. I'll to Fairfax ; h. H e
Gave hope , and& hope is life.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Farewell!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: That word—
I prythee speak it not ! —withers me, lives
Like a serpent's hiss within mine ear, sho uo ts through
My veins like poison, twines and& coils about me
Clinging and& killing. 'Tis a sound accurst,
A word of death and& doom .! Why shouldst thou speak it?

app.rdg: Thou shalt be saved; Fairfax shall save thee. Charles,
Thou shalt be saved! Fairfax shall save thee!—-Charles—-

sp.l: Give me a ringlet of thy hair— No, no—No! no!
Not now! N ot now! — Thou shalt not die.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sweet wife ,
Say to my children that my last fond thought—

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Last! Thou shalt live to tell them of thy thoughts
Longer than they or I to hear thee. Harken!
Promise thou wilt await me here !. Let none—
They will not dare, they shall not. I but waste
The hour. To Fairfax, the good Fairfax! Charles
Thou shalt not die !

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh fondest truesttruest fondest woman!
My matchless wife! — The pang is mastered now,!
I am Death's conqueror.— My Faithfullest!

My Fairest! My most
- dear! I ne'er shallshall ne'er see
Those radiant looks again, or hear the sound
Of thy blytheb voice, which was a hope, or feel
The thrilling pressure of thy hand, almost
A language, so the ardent spirit burned
And vibrated within thee ! .— I'll to prayer,
And chase away that image ! .— I'll to prayer ,—
And pray for thee , sweet wife! I'll to my prayers.

app.rdg: Scene—The Banqueting-house at Whitehall; glass folding doors opening on the scaffold, which is covered with black; the block axe & visible. Officers & other persons are busy in the back-ground. Cromwell giving directions. Ireton, Hacker, & Harrison meeting. Cromwell! behind.

—The Banquetting-House at Whitehall, glass folding-doors opening to the Scaffold, which is covered with black. The block, axe, &c. visible ; Officers and other persons are busy inthe background, and Cromwell is also there giving directions.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Cromwell!—Good - morrow Ireton !. Whither goes
The General?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: To see that all be ready
For this great deed.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.l: He hath the eager step,
The dark light in his eye, the upward look,
The flush upon his cheek , that I've marked in him
When marching to the battle.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Doth he not lead
To day in a great combat, a most holy
And glorious victory?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.stage: (at the back of the Ss tage)
sp.l: Hast thou ta'en order
That soon as the head's off the Abbey bell
Begin to toll?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Look that the axe

Be keen ,
and& the hand steady. Let us have
No butchery.
sp.stage: (advancing to the front of the sS tage. )
sp.l: If he die not, we must perish—
The liberty for which the blood of saints
And martyrs hath been spilt, freedom of act ,
Of speech, of will , of faith! Better one gr ea y
Discrowned head should fall, albeit a thought
Before the time, than God's own people groan

In slavery for
ever.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Whoso doubteth
But he shall die?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: 'Tis rumoured, Sirs, amongst ,
The soldiery , that one of a high place,
Fairfax—But I believe it not. Hast thou
The Ww arrant Hacker?

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.l: No.
Since when doth Fairfax
Dare to impugn the sentence of a free
And public k court, of England —, of the Great

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: All-Righteous Judge , who hath delivered him
Manifestly to us?
Will he dare oppose
Army &and people? Hh e alone !?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Be sure
The good Lord - General, howsoe'er some scruple
May trouble him, will play a godly part
In this sad drama.—Aye , I have the Ww arrant !.
It is addressed to thee. Thou must receive
The prisoner ,&and conduct him hither.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.l: Hath
The hour been yet resolved?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Not that I hear.
Ha ! our great General! Well met my Ll ord!
We that are laden with this heavy burthen
Lacked your sustaining aid !.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Cromwell , I too
Am heavy - laden.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: You look ill at ease;
'Tis this chill air, the nourisher of rheums,
The very fog of frost, that turns men's blood
To water.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: No !, the grief is here. Regret,
Almost remorse, &and doubt &and fear of wrong
Press heavwear ily upon me. Is this death
Lawful?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: His country's sentence, good my Ll ord,
May be thy warrant.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: An anointed King!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: A bloody tyrant.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Yet a man, whose doom

Lies on our conscience.
( Tt o Cromwell)
We might save the King
Even now at the eleventh hour ; w. W e two
Hold the nice scales of life &and death, &and shall not
Fair mM ercy sway the balance? Dost thou hear me?
Wilt thou not answer? Canst thou doubt our power?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: No. Man hath always power for ill. I know
We might desert our friends, betray our country,
Abandon our great cause, &and sell our souls

To Hell — . We might do do
this ,&and more; might shroud
These devilish sins in holy names, &and call them
Loyalty, Honour, Faith, Repentance —c. C heats
Which the great Tempter loves !.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l:
Yet hearken ,
Cromwell!
Bethink thee of thy fame !

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Talk'st thou of fame
To me? I am too mean a man, too lowly,
Too poor in state &and name to need abjure
That princely sin, &and for my humbleness
I duly render thanks. Were I as thou—
Beware the lust of fame, Lord General ,!
Of perishable fame, vain breath of man ,!
Slight bubble, frailer than the ocean foam
Which from her prow the good ship in her course
Scattereth and& passeth on regardlessly.
Lord General beware!

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: I am Lord General ;,
And I alone by mine own voice have power
To stay this deed.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Alone?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: I'll answer it
Before the Council.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l:
Ha! aA lone! —
cC ome nearer .!

rdg.emph: (advancing to the front of the stage)

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: What would ' st thou ofwith me?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Yonder men are firm
And honest in the cause, &and brave as steel; —
Yet are they zealots, blind &and furious zealots!
I would not they should hear us— bB loody zealots!

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Speak , Sir !; we waste the hour.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I would confess
Relentings like thine own . —They hear us not?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: I joy to hear thee.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Thou art one elect,
A leader in the land, a chosen vessel ,
And yet of such a mild &and gracious mood,
That I, stern as I seem, may doff to thee
This smooth &and governed mask of polity,
And shew the struggling heart perplexed and& grieved
In all its nakedness. Yes ,! I have known
The kindly natural love of man to man
His fellow !—, the rough soldier's shuddering hate
Of violent death , save in the battle ;, lastly
A passionate yearning for that sweetest power
Born of fair Mercy.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Yet but now thou chidd'st me
And with a lofty scorn for such a weakness.
The change is sudden.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Good my lL ord , I strove
And wrestled with each pitying thought as born
Of earthly pride and& mortal sin. Full oft
We , that are watchers of our wretched selves ,
Aiming at phigher virtues , trample down
Fair shoots of charity &and gentle love,

Yet still my breast was troubled ;.
and& since thou
Art moved by such relentings—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: And a promise
Made to my wife.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: A wise &and pious lady!

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Thou wilt then save the King?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sir !, we must have
Some higher warrantry than our wild will ,
Our treacherous human will , afore we change
The fiat of a nation. Thou art a man
Elect &and godly. —Harrison!— gG o seek
The presence of the Lord. Perhaps to thee
A guiding answer , a divine impulsion,
May be vouchsafed. Go with him Harrison!
Seek ye the Lord together.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: 'Tis a fairwise
And pious counsel.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Step apart awhile;
We will await ye here.
sp.stage:
Exeunt Fairfax
&and
Harrison. (Cromwell then gives the warrant to Hacker.)

app.rdg: Cromwell gives the Warrant to Hacker.)

sp.l: Now! nN ow! bB e quick!
Is the scaffold all prepared? The headsman waiting
With shrouded visage &and bare arm? The axe
Whetted? Be ready on the instant. Where
Be guards to line the room, mute wondering faces,
A living tapestry, &and men of place
To witness this great deed? A King should fall
Decked with the pageantries of Death, the clouds
That roll around the setting sun.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: If Fairfax
Return before he come—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Dost thou mistrust
Harrison's gift in prayer? The General's safe.
Besides I sent erewhile the Halberdiers
To guard Charles Stuart hither. Hacker'll meet
His prisoner.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: But should Fairfax—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Wherefore waste
A word on such a waverer !?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: What hath swayed him?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: His wife! his wife! The Queen hath seen again
That haughty dame, &and her fond tears—

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: I marvel
That thou endur'st that popish witch of France
So near.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I watch her. He must die !. 'Tis borne
Upon my soul as what shall be. The race,
The name shall perish.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Aye , the very name
Of King.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Of Stuart.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: And of King.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: So be it.
Will Bradshaw never come?
Ah welcome! welcome!
Ye are late.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Yon living mass is hard to pierce
By men of civil calling. The armed soldiers
Can scantly force a passage for their prisoner.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: He comes?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: He's at the gate.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: What say the people ?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: The most are pale and& silent, as a Fear
Hung its dull shadow over them; whilst some
Struck with a sudden pity weep and& wonder
In execration.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: And the soldiers?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They
Are true to the good cause.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The righteous cause!
My friends and& comrades ye are come to witness
The mighty consummation. See , the sun
Breaks forth! The Heavens look down upon our work
Smiling! The Lord hath risen!

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: The King!

div.stage: Enter the King, Hacker, Herbert, a Bishop, Gg uards , &c.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why pause ye?
Come on .!

app.rdg: Herbert gives the King a letter.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: (giving the King a letter) Sir e , from thy Ss on.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My boy! My boy!
No; no;No, no, this letter is of life, &and I
And life have shaken hands. My kK ingly boy!
And the fair girl! I thought to have done with this .—

But it so clings! Take back the letter ,
Herbert .!
Take it , I say. Forgive me , faithful Herbert,
That last impatient word .! Forgive me .!— Now , Sirs ,
What see ye on that platform? I am as one
Bent on a far &and perilous voyage, who seeks
To hear what rocks beset his track.—path. What see ye?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Only the black-masked headsman.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye , he wears
His mask upon his face ,; an honest mask .!
What see ye more?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Nought , save the living sea
Of human faces, blent into one mass
Of sentient various life :; woman and& man,
Childhood &and infancy ,&and youth &and age ,
Commingled , with its multitudinous eyes
Upturned in expectation. Aweful gaze !
Who may abide thy power ?!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I shall look upward.
Why pause we here?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l:
Aye,
why !!?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: May it please thee, Sir,
To rest awhile? Bring wine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I need it not.
Yes! fill the cup! fill high the sparkling cup!
This is a holiday to loyal breasts,
The King's accession day. Fill high! fill high!

The block, the scaffold, the
quick
swift sudden axe ,
Have yet a privilege beyond the slow
And painful dying bed, &and I may quaff
In my full pride of strength a health to him,

app.rdg: Whom, pass one short half-hour, the funeral knell
Whom in one short half hour my funeral knell

sp.l: Proclaims my successor :—. Health to my son!
Health to the King of England! — Start ye, Sirs,

To hear the word? Health to King Charles ,!and
& peace ,
To this fair realm! And when that blessed time
Of rightful rule shall come, say that I left
For the bold traitors that condemned, the cowards
WhoThat not opposing murdered me — (I have won
So near the Tthrone of Truth that true words spring
A pardon , liberal as the air , to all ,
A free &and royal pardon!—Prythee speed me
On my rough journey.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Wherefore crowd ye there?
Make way .!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I thank thee , Sir. My good Lord Bishop ,
Beware the step. —

app.rdg: (Exeunt King, Herbert, Bishop, and Guards. A pause.)

rdg.emph: Exeunt King, Herbert, Bishop, and guards. A pause.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Doth he address the people?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not so . H, h e kneels.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: 'Twere fittest. Close the door .
This wintery air iscomes chill, and& the Lord President
Is of a feeble body.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: H ushark !

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: 'Tis one
Who must be stayed.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: The Queen?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l:
Go stop her ,
Ireton .!
It were not meet that earthly loves should mingle
With yonder dying prayer. Yes! Still he kneels.
Hacker come hither .! If thou see a stir
Amongst the crowd, send for my horse ;, they're ready ;—.
Or if , midst these grave men , some feeble heart
Wax faint in the great cause ,— as such there be ;! —
Or on the scaffold, if he cling to life
Before his time to his accomptaccount, good Bradshaw! —
But no delay! — Is he still kneeling?—Mark me ,
No idle dalliance Hacker! I must hence,
Lest Fairfax— noNo weak dalliance! noNo delay! —
The cause ,! the cause ,! good Bradshaw!

app.rdg: Scene—another gallery in Whitehall. Enter Enter Cromwell.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Methought I heard her here . —No!—if she win
To Fairfax ! — hH e must die, as Ahab erst ,
Or Rehoboam,; or as that great hHeathen
Whom Brutus loved and& slew. None ever called
Brutus a murderer! And Charles had trial —,
'Twas more than Caesar had !—, free open trial,
If he had pleaded.; But the Eternal Wrath
Stiffened him in his pride. It was ordained,
And I but an impassive instrument
In the Almighty hand,; an arrow chosen
From out the sheaf. If I should reign hereafter
Men shall not call me bloody . —Hark! the bell! —
No—all is hush as midnight . —I shall be
Tenderer of English lives. Have they forgot
To sound the bell? He must be dead.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Lord Fairfax!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The Queen! the Queen!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: They told me he was here;—
And then that axe, that keen, bright, edgy axe,
Which flashed across my eyeballs, blinding me
More than a sea of tears.—Here's one ! : —Oh fly,
If thou be man, and bid the hHeadsman stay
His blow for one short hour, one little hour,
Till I have found Lord Fairfax! Thou shalt have

app.rdg: Gold, mines of gold! Oh save him! Save the King!
Gold, mines of gold. Fly! Save him! Save the King!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Peace! pPeace! Have comfort!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Comfort! aAnd he dies,!
They murder him;! the axe falls on his neck;!
The blood comes plashing ;—! Comfort!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: Out alas!
I can hear nought of Fairfax, royal Madam !—.
Cromwell, the Master-murderer!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Oh forgive her!
She knows not what she says. If thou be Cromwell
Thou hast the power to rescue:. See I kneel;,
I kiss thy feet. Oh save him! Take the crown;,
Take all but his dear life! Oh save him, save him!
And I will be thy slave! — I , a born Princess,
I, a crowned Queen, will be thy slave.!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Arise!
My Lady Fairfax lead this frantic woman
To where her children bide.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thou wilt not make
My children fatherless? Oh mercy! Mmercy!
I have a girl, a weeping innocent girl,
That never learnt to smile, &and she shall be
Thy handmaid; she shall tend thy daughters.; I,
That was so proud, offer my fairest child
To be thy bondwoman.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Raise her! Undo
These clasping hands.! I marvel, Lady Fairfax,
Thou canst endure to see a creature kneel
To one create.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: Out on thee, hHypocrite!
Where lags my husband?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Save him!, save him, Cromwell!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Woman arise! Will this long agony
Endure forever?
sp.stage: Enter Ireton, on one side, followed by Fairfax and Harrison on the other.
sp.l: Is he dead?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: What means
This piercing outcry?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Fairfax! He is saved!
He is saved!

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: The bell! the Abbey bell! Hark!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: There
The will of Heaven spake.; The King is dead.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Look to the Queen. Cromwell, this bloody work
Is thine.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: This work is mine. For yon sad dame,
She shall away to France. This deed is mine,
And I will answer it. The Commonwealth
Is firmly 'stablished Ireton. Harrison,
The Saints shall rule in Israel. My Lord General,
The army is thine own, &and I a soldier,
A lowly follower in the cCause. An X in ink appears here in another hand, likely to mark the end of the manuscript.This deed
Is mine.—

app.rdg:
END OF THE PLAY.

org.note: The Commissioners of the trial of Charles I who signed his death warrant on January 29, 1649.

The House of Lancaster, which had as its insignia the Red Rose, fought the Wars of the Roses with the House of York (the "White Rose"). Both houses became extinct--in mainstream, accepted, evidence-based history, anyway--with the marriage of the Lancastrian Henry VII and Elizabeth of York.

person.note: Herbert was a Parliamentarian during the English Civil Wars. He served as Charles I's Gentleman of the Bedchamber from 1647 to 1649, during the King's imprisonment. In the 1650s he followed the New Model Army to Ireland, where he served in several governmental posts. He returned to England after the Restoration and received a baronetcy from Charles II. Historical opinion was divided on his loyalty to Charles I; while the Parliamentarians clearly believed him to be loyal to their cause in the 1640s and 1650s, in 1678 he published a memoir covering the time of his service to Charles in which he portrays himself as extremely loyal to the monarchy.

A republican and Parliamentarian, Marten supported the New Model Army and the establishment of the Commonwealth. Member of Parliament for Berkshire during the Short Parliament and the Long Parliament. After the outbreak of the English Civil War, he was appointed governor of Reading, Berkshire. He was one of the signers of the death warrant of Charles I and was found guilty of regicide. Through the inaction of the House of Lords, he was not executed in 1660 but remained imprisoned until his death in 1680.

Trained in the law, he served as Member of Parliament for Arundel, Sussex. He was one of the signers of the death warrant of Charles I and was found guilty of regicide. His sentence was commuted to life imprisonment in 1660 and he remained in the Tower of London until his death in 1666.

As Solicitor General for the High Court of Justice, he led the prosecution of Charles I. For his part in the trial, he was found guilty of high treason and was hanged, drawn and quartered at Tyburn on October 16, 1660.

Pride was a Parliamentary general during the Civil Wars. He was responsible for carrying out "Pride's Purge" of Parliament in 1648, which ended the Long Parliament and marked the start of the Rump Parliament who tried Charles I. He was one of the signers of the death warrant of Charles I and was posthumously found guilty of regicide.

An officer in the New Model Army. A Commissioner at the High Court of Justicein the trial of Charles I. He did not sign the death warrant, for reasons that remain unclear. Although he died before the Restoration, he was exempted from the Indemnity and Oblivion Act, and his family's property seized.

Youngest son of Charles I and Henrietta Maria. He visited his father in prison, as depicted in Charles the First, before leaving for exile in Continental Europe. At the Restoration in 1660, he returned to England with his elder brother Charles II, only to die shortly thereafter of smallpox.

The second daughter of Charles I and Queen Henrietta Maria. She was imprisoned during the English Civil Wars from age six to her death from pneumonia in 1650 at age fourteen. She is portrayed as a girl aged twelve, in Mitford's play, Charles I.

persName.roleName: Queen Consort of England, Scotland and Ireland

person.note: Daughter of Henry IV of France and Marie de Medici. House of Bourbon. Spouse of Charles I and mother of Charles II and , she was called Maria or Mary while in England.
Apocryphal Old Testament figure from the Christian Bible. Famous for seducing then beheading the Assyrian general Holofernes.
Apocryphal Old Testament prophet from the Christian Bible; he related his visions to King David.

Old Testament figure from the Christian Bible. Apocryphal king of a united kingdom of Israel and Judah. Portrayed as a shepherd and musician, as well as the killer of Goliath and a favored courtier of King Saul.

New Testament figure from the Christian Bible. One of Jesus's twelve disciples or Apostles, According to the gospels, Peter was a fisherman, had a leadership role amongst the disciples, and denied Jesus three times and later repented. Peter later became the first Bishop of Rome, Pope of the Catholic Church, according to Catholic tradition. Patriarch of Antioch in the Eastern Christian tradition.

New Testament figure from the Christian Bible. One of the Jesus's twelve disciples or Apostles, remembered principally as the betrayer of Jesus Christ. His name came to have the colloquially meaning of "traitor."
In As You Like It, the character of Duke Senior, the older brother of the usurping Duke Frederick, and father to Rosalind.

place.note: The European continent, extending in the thinking of Mitford's time roughly south to the Middle East and east to St. Petersburg, and bounded on the west by the Atlantic.

A region of the Kingdom of the Netherlands. Until the Napoleonic invasion of 1795, part of the United Provinces of the Netherlands. After Napoleon abolished the Netherlands' historic Republic (founded in the sixteenth century), "Holland" gradually become colloquial for "the Netherlands," and today the two geographic entities are frequently conflated. Charles II and other exiled Stuarts took refuge in Holland and France.

The ocean that extends between, on the Eastern side, Europe and Africa, and, on the West, the New World (the Americas.) Historically known as the Sea of Atlas, after the ancient Greek mythological character who holds up the world.

The largest and the oldest-occupied castle in the world, Windsor Castle was built by William the Conqueror (William I) circa 1070, with the presently-existing buildings commissioned by Henry II, Henry III and Edward III. During Mitford's lifetime, Windsor Castle saw a series of renovations under George III, George IV, and became one of the primary residences of the British royal family. From 1810 on, George IIIwas confined to the State Apartments at the Castle during his illness.

Now an inner London borough centrally located in Greater London; historically a separate entity west of the City of London and the site of Westminster Abbey and the Palace of Westminster. Westminster has served as the seat of English government since the eleventh-century reign of King Edward the Confessor. Until the sixteenth century, Westminster was geographically separated from London by relatively undeveloped land. After this space was built up, in 1604, the City and Liberty of Westminster was established by James I. In Mitford's time, a district of Greater London and the location of St. James's Palace, Buckingham Palace, and the Houses of Parliament; of shopping districts around Bond Street, Regent Street, and Oxford Street; and of the fashionable residential and theater districts of the West End.

Built in the early sixteenth century by Cardinal Wolseley, then, after Wolseley's fall, the residence of Henry VIII, Hampton Court Palace has been the residence of royals including George II, who was the last monarch to occupy it as an official residence. Charles I spent part of his house arrest there during his imprisonment by Parliament.

Fictional Forest of Arden, setting for As You Like It. Variously identified with historical and fictional representations of the Forest of Ardennes in continental Europe, and with Arden, a heavily wooded area of Warwickshire, England.

event.label: English Civil Wars
event.note: A series of conflicts between British Parliamentarians, supporters of Oliver Cromwell, and Royalists, supporters of Stuart King Charles I, fought between 1642 and 1651. Also called The Great Rebellion or The War of Three Kingdoms, as civil war broke out in all three Stuart kingdoms of England, Scotland, and Ireland. The war was fought principally over the questions of government (the relation between the monarch and Parliament, as defined through England's constitutional framework) and religion (the Church of England's monopoly on Christian worship in England). The first war ended with a Parliamentarian victory at Naseby in 1645 and resulted in the creation of the New Model Army and an alliance between the Parliamentarians and the Scottish Covenanters. The second ended with a Parliamentary victory at Preston and culminated with the execution of Charles I in 1649. The third war was led by Charles II with Scottish and Irish allies and ended at Worcester in 1651 with Charles II's retreat to France.

event.label: Commonwealth of England
event.note: The Commonwealth refers to the period of time when England was governed as a republic, between the execution of King Charles I in 1649 and the assumption by Oliver Cromwell of the title Lord Protector, in 1653. The period that followed (1653 to 1660) is called the Protectorate. "An Act declaring England to be a Commonwealth" by the Rump Parliament called the republic into existence on May 19, 1649. Under the Commonwealth, decision-making power was held by Parliament and by a Council of State. Some refer to the entire period from 1649 to 1660 as the Commonwealth.

event.label: Commonwealth of England
event.note: The Protectorate refers to the period of time when England and Wales, Scotland and Ireland was governed by a Lord Protector. Oliver Cromwell assumed the title under the "Instrument of Government" in 1653. Upon Oliver Cromwell's death, his son Richard assumed the title. The Protectorate was dissolved by the Committee of Safety in 1659, and the Rump Parliament and Council of State together governed briefly until the restoration of the monarchy in 1660.

event.label: Appearance of Halley's Comet
event.note: A short-period comet visible to the naked eye from earth, it appears every 74 to 79 years. In 1705, it was named for the English astronomer Edmond Halley, who correctly identified its periodic recurrence. Records exist dating the comet's appearance back to at least 240 B.C. The comet had been visible from England in 1066 when William the Conqueror's victory founded the modern English dynasty; it is depicted in the Bayeux Tapestry's representation of the Battle of Hastings. Mitford's character of Charles I associates the comet with cataclysmic regime change.

event.label: Treaty of Newport
event.note: Ultimately unsuccessful treaty negotiations conducted in fall 1648 between Charles I and Parliament, intended to bring an end to the English Civil War. Held at Newport on the Isle of Wight. Parliament annulled the Treaty on 13 December 1648.

event.label: Trial of Charles I
event.note: Charles I was tried before the Commissioners of the High Court of Justice, appointed by the Rump House of Commons, beginning on January 20, 1648. He was convicted of treason and other high crimes and was sentenced to death on January 27, 1648. Solicitor General John Cook led the prosecution before the appointed Commissioners, fifty-nine of whom ultimately signed the Death warrant.

bibl.title: Death Warrant of Charles Stuart
bibl.note: The warrant for the execution of Charles I for treason, signed on January 29, 1649 by fifty-nine Commissioners, now known as the regicides.
